questions.source_summary: Berscheid's (1991) emotion-in-relationships model identifies unexpected behaviors that interrupt usual behavioral routines as a cause of strong emotions in close relationships.
questions.vignette: A researcher studying long-term partnerships observes that two people who have shared a home for 18 years rarely seem to argue or express dramatic feelings toward each other during ordinary weeks. One autumn, one partner accepts a temporary teaching assignment abroad for three months, and both partners report that the period leading up to and immediately following the departure was the most emotionally charged of their entire relationship — marked by heightened affection, unexpected bouts of crying, irritability over trivial matters, and an almost euphoric quality to their last week together. When the partner returns three months later, both describe a second wave of intense emotion that surprises them given how much they had looked forward to the reunion. The researcher notes that the couples who reported the greatest emotional intensity at departure and return were also the ones whose daily schedules, household tasks, social plans, and leisure activities had been most thoroughly organized around each other before the separation.
questions.question: Which theoretical model best accounts for the pattern the researcher observes across these couples?

options.A: Attachment theory, emphasizing activation of the attachment behavioral system during separation
options.B: Excitation transfer theory, in which residual arousal from anticipatory stress amplifies emotional reactions at reunion
options.C: Berscheid's emotion-in-relationships model, in which emotional intensity follows from disruption of tightly interlocked behavioral routines
options.D: Social exchange theory, in which departure and return alter the perceived ratio of relational costs and rewards

option_explanations.A: Attachment theory would predict that separation activates the attachment behavioral system, producing anxiety, protest, and heightened affection — and this maps convincingly onto the crying, irritability, and heightened affection described at departure. However, attachment theory does not specifically predict that emotional intensity at separation and reunion will be proportional to the degree to which the couple's daily activities were organized around each other; that specific relationship is the hallmark of Berscheid's model, not attachment theory.
option_explanations.B: Excitation transfer theory would predict that physiological arousal generated by anticipatory stress before departure lingers and is then misattributed to the emotional quality of the reunion, amplifying it — which could explain the second wave of intense emotion at return. However, excitation transfer requires a temporal gap in which residual arousal is misidentified, and the vignette does not describe arousal from a prior distinct source being transferred; moreover, it does not explain why couples with more integrated daily schedules showed greater intensity.
option_explanations.C: Berscheid's emotion-in-relationships model holds that the intensity of emotion in close relationships is directly tied to how thoroughly a partner's behavior is woven into one's own ongoing behavioral routines. When those routines are disrupted — by departure or return — the interruption generates strong emotional responses. The researcher's key finding that emotional intensity is proportional to how thoroughly the couples had organized their lives around each other is the precise prediction of Berscheid's model, distinguishing it from attachment, excitation transfer, and social exchange accounts.
option_explanations.D: Social exchange theory would predict that departure increases costs (loneliness, lost support) and reduces rewards, temporarily lowering satisfaction, while return restores them — which might produce emotional reactions at both transitions. However, social exchange theory does not predict that emotional intensity at those transitions will be proportional to the degree of prior daily schedule integration; it focuses on cost-benefit ratios rather than the structure of behavioral interdependence that Berscheid's model emphasizes.

questions.source_summary: A meta-analysis by Rhodes and Wood (1992) concluded that moderate levels of self-esteem and low levels of intelligence are associated with the greatest susceptibility to persuasion.
questions.vignette: A social psychologist is reviewing a meta-analysis examining which individual characteristics predict susceptibility to persuasion. The study finds that participants with moderate levels of self-esteem and lower levels of intelligence show the highest rates of attitude change following exposure to persuasive messages. The researcher notes that people with very high or very low self-esteem appear less susceptible to these influence attempts. These findings have direct implications for targeting persuasive health communications.
questions.question: According to the meta-analytic findings described, which individual difference profile is most associated with susceptibility to persuasion?

option_explanations.A: Incorrect. High self-esteem is associated with greater resistance to persuasion because individuals feel confident in their existing attitudes. High intelligence also enables more critical evaluation of persuasive arguments, further reducing susceptibility.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Although low self-esteem might seem to imply vulnerability, Rhodes and Wood (1992) found that very low self-esteem actually reduces persuasion susceptibility, possibly because such individuals disengage from messages entirely. High intelligence independently enables better argument scrutiny.
option_explanations.C: Correct. Rhodes and Wood's (1992) meta-analysis specifically found that moderate self-esteem (which balances receptivity with engagement) combined with low intelligence (which limits critical counterarguing) produces the greatest susceptibility to persuasive messages.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Very low self-esteem, despite seeming to imply heightened vulnerability, is associated with reduced persuasibility because those individuals may lack the motivation or engagement to process messages. Moderate, not low, self-esteem is the key predictor.

questions.source_summary: A meta-analysis by Rhodes and Wood (1992) concluded that moderate levels of self-esteem and low levels of intelligence are associated with the greatest susceptibility to persuasion.
questions.vignette: A public health campaign designer is consulting research on audience targeting to maximize the effectiveness of an anti-smoking persuasion campaign. She reads a large meta-analysis indicating that self-esteem level is a key moderator of persuasibility, with moderate levels producing the greatest attitude change. The consultant is 45 years old and notes that her own high level of education may complicate how she personally responds to such campaigns. The findings suggest that cognitive capacity is also a significant moderator of how readily people are persuaded.
questions.question: Based on the research findings described, which combination of individual characteristics best predicts the greatest susceptibility to persuasive messages?

options.A: Moderate self-esteem and lower cognitive ability
options.B: High self-esteem and high cognitive ability
options.C: Low self-esteem and lower cognitive ability
options.D: Moderate self-esteem and high cognitive ability

option_explanations.A: Correct. Rhodes and Wood (1992) found that moderate self-esteem — where individuals are engaged and open enough to be influenced — combined with lower cognitive ability — which limits their capacity to generate counterarguments — produces the highest degree of persuasibility.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. High self-esteem promotes resistance to persuasion because individuals are confident in their existing attitudes. High cognitive ability further allows for effective evaluation and rebuttal of persuasive arguments, compounding resistance.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. Low self-esteem, counterintuitively, does not maximize persuasibility. Very low self-esteem may lead to disengagement from the persuasive message rather than attitude change, so it is moderate self-esteem that predicts greatest susceptibility.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. While moderate self-esteem is indeed the key self-esteem predictor, high cognitive ability allows individuals to critically analyze persuasive messages and generate counterarguments, thereby reducing susceptibility rather than increasing it.

questions.source_summary: A meta-analysis by Rhodes and Wood (1992) concluded that moderate levels of self-esteem and low levels of intelligence are associated with the greatest susceptibility to persuasion.
questions.vignette: A researcher presents findings from a large meta-analysis at a social influence conference, examining how personality and ability variables moderate attitude change following exposure to arguments. Notably, the data show a curvilinear pattern for one personality variable — those scoring at the extreme ends of the distribution on this variable show less attitude change than those near the middle. The researcher emphasizes that this curvilinear relationship has frequently been overlooked in applied settings, where practitioners often assume that the most psychologically vulnerable individuals will be most easily influenced. A second variable in the study shows a straightforward linear pattern: lower scores consistently predict greater attitude change.
questions.question: Which combination of variables most accurately reflects the meta-analytic finding described in the vignette?

options.A: Moderate neuroticism and low need for cognition
options.C: Low self-esteem and low need for cognition
options.D: Moderate openness to experience and low intelligence

option_explanations.B: Correct. The curvilinear pattern described matches the self-esteem finding in Rhodes and Wood (1992): those with moderate self-esteem are most susceptible, while those at the extremes (very high or very low) are less so. The linear predictor — where lower scores consistently predict more attitude change — matches intelligence, which declines persuasibility as it increases.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Neuroticism does not have an established curvilinear relationship with persuasibility in the social influence literature. Need for cognition is a related but distinct construct; while low need for cognition does reduce elaboration, this pairing does not accurately reflect the Rhodes and Wood findings.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. Low self-esteem would represent an extreme — not a moderate — point on the distribution, and the vignette specifies a curvilinear pattern where middle-range scores predict most attitude change. Very low self-esteem is associated with disengagement, not heightened persuasibility.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Openness to experience is a Big Five personality trait associated with receptivity to new ideas, but Rhodes and Wood's meta-analysis specifically identified self-esteem — not openness — as exhibiting the curvilinear pattern. Intelligence, not openness, is the linearly related ability variable in these findings.

questions.source_summary: A meta-analysis by Rhodes and Wood (1992) concluded that moderate levels of self-esteem and low levels of intelligence are associated with the greatest susceptibility to persuasion.
questions.vignette: At an industry seminar on consumer behavior, a market researcher presents data showing that a persuasive advertising campaign was most effective among individuals who scored in the middle range on a widely used measure of personal confidence and security. Paradoxically, the campaign had little effect on both the group scoring lowest on this measure — despite this group being considered the most 'at-risk' for influence by the campaign team — and on those scoring highest. Additionally, the researcher notes that the campaign's weakest results were observed among those with higher verbal reasoning scores, because these individuals engaged in active counterarguing when exposed to the ads. The team initially attributed the campaign's success to message framing rather than audience characteristics.
questions.question: The pattern of results described in this vignette is most consistent with which of the following findings from the social influence literature?

options.A: The peripheral route to persuasion is more effective than the central route for high-ability audiences
options.B: Moderate self-esteem and low intelligence are associated with the greatest susceptibility to persuasion
options.C: Low need for cognition predicts greater reliance on heuristics and thus higher persuasibility
options.D: High susceptibility to normative social influence is inversely related to cognitive complexity

option_explanations.B: Correct. The curvilinear relationship with 'personal confidence and security' (a behavioral descriptor for self-esteem) — where middle scores predict most attitude change and extremes do not — combined with the inverse relationship between verbal reasoning (a proxy for intelligence) and susceptibility through counterarguing, precisely matches Rhodes and Wood's (1992) meta-analytic finding.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. The Elaboration Likelihood Model's central vs. peripheral route distinction concerns the process of attitude change, not individual difference profiles. While high-ability audiences do prefer central route processing, this framework does not predict the curvilinear self-esteem pattern described, nor does it directly address why low scorers on confidence were resistant.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. Need for cognition refers to the intrinsic motivation to engage in effortful thinking. While those low in need for cognition do rely more on peripheral cues and heuristics, this variable does not produce a curvilinear pattern with susceptibility — it relates linearly — and the vignette's central puzzle is the non-obvious pattern at the low end of the confidence variable.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Normative social influence concerns conformity pressure from others and the desire for social acceptance, which is conceptually distinct from persuasion by message arguments. Cognitive complexity does moderate some social influence processes, but this framework does not account for the specific curvilinear relationship with self-esteem described here.

questions.source_summary: A meta-analysis by Rhodes and Wood (1992) concluded that moderate levels of self-esteem and low levels of intelligence are associated with the greatest susceptibility to persuasion.
questions.vignette: A consultant reviewing results from three advertising test groups is puzzled by an unexpected pattern. The group she predicted would be most easily swayed — people who had scored poorly on a brief self-evaluation and generally thought little of themselves — actually showed the least change in their purchasing intentions after exposure to the campaign. In contrast, people who held a reasonably balanced, neither particularly positive nor particularly negative view of themselves showed the most movement. A third moderating variable also emerged: among those with higher scores on a standardized verbal test administered before the study, the campaign had negligible effects regardless of the first variable, apparently because these individuals generated objections to the campaign's claims as they viewed it.
questions.question: The pattern of consumer behavior described in this vignette is best explained by which of the following findings?

options.A: Individuals low in need for cognition are most susceptible to persuasion because they rely on simple heuristic cues rather than argument quality
options.B: Moderate self-esteem and low intelligence are associated with the greatest susceptibility to persuasion
options.C: Individuals with low self-esteem are most vulnerable to social influence because they are motivated to seek approval from others
options.D: High verbal ability leads to deeper elaboration of persuasive messages, thereby strengthening rather than weakening attitude change

option_explanations.B: Correct. The vignette describes exactly the pattern in Rhodes and Wood (1992): those with very low self-evaluations (low self-esteem) are not most susceptible — a common misconception — while those in the middle range show the most attitude change. The verbal test moderates susceptibility inversely, consistent with the finding that lower intelligence is associated with greater persuasibility because high-ability individuals generate effective counterarguments.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Need for cognition predicts reliance on heuristics vs. arguments, but it does not produce a curvilinear relationship with susceptibility — individuals low in need for cognition are simply less likely to elaborate, not uniquely situated at a middle point on the distribution. The vignette's key puzzle — that the lowest self-evaluation group was least susceptible — is not explained by this framework.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. While it is intuitive that low self-esteem should predict susceptibility (because such individuals might seek approval), this is precisely the misconception that Rhodes and Wood's findings correct. Very low self-esteem is associated with reduced persuasibility, possibly because these individuals are less engaged with or motivated by external messages. The vignette explicitly shows the low self-evaluation group resisting the campaign.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. The Elaboration Likelihood Model does not predict that high verbal ability strengthens attitude change — rather, high ability to process arguments allows for effective counterarguing, which reduces attitude change when the message quality is low or moderate. The vignette describes this inverse relationship correctly, but option D mischaracterizes it as a positive relationship.

questions.source_summary: The self-serving bias is the tendency to attribute our successes to dispositional factors and our failures to situational factors.
questions.subdomain: Social Cognition - Errors, Biases, and Heuristics
questions.vignette: A graduate student receives an excellent grade on her statistics exam and tells her classmates, 'I've always been analytically gifted — this just proves it.' Two weeks later, she fails a chemistry quiz and immediately explains to her study group, 'The professor wrote unfair questions and the room was unbearably noisy.' Her pattern of attribution is consistent across multiple academic outcomes throughout the semester. A social psychology professor observing her pattern notes that it reflects a well-documented attribution error.
questions.question: Which concept BEST explains the graduate student's pattern of attributing her exam success to dispositional factors and her failure to situational factors?

option_explanations.A: The actor-observer bias refers to the tendency to attribute one's own behavior to situational factors while attributing others' behavior to dispositional factors — it does not specifically involve the asymmetric crediting of successes versus failures to oneself, which is what this vignette describes.
option_explanations.B: The self-serving bias is the tendency to attribute personal successes to internal, dispositional factors (e.g., talent) while attributing personal failures to external, situational factors (e.g., unfair questions), which precisely matches the student's pattern across both outcomes.
option_explanations.C: The fundamental attribution error is the general tendency to overweight dispositional causes and underweight situational causes when explaining OTHER people's behavior. This student is explaining her own behavior, making fundamental attribution error an incorrect fit.
option_explanations.D: Unrealistic optimism is the belief that one is less likely than others to experience negative events and more likely to experience positive events. While related to positive self-perception, it does not involve causal attribution patterns for past outcomes, as described here.

questions.source_summary: The self-serving bias is the tendency to attribute our successes to dispositional factors and our failures to situational factors.
questions.subdomain: Social Cognition - Errors, Biases, and Heuristics
questions.vignette: A 34-year-old sales manager who has been in therapy for mild anxiety disorder receives a large quarterly bonus and proudly tells his therapist, 'I worked harder than anyone else and I'm simply better at reading clients.' When his team fails to meet its targets the following quarter, he tells the therapist that upper management gave him an impossible quota and that two of his best salespeople were out sick. His therapist notes that this ego-protective attribution pattern has appeared repeatedly in the client's narratives, and appears unrelated to his anxiety symptoms.
questions.question: Which social psychological phenomenon BEST accounts for the sales manager's consistent pattern of causal explanation?

option_explanations.A: The self-serving bias describes the consistent tendency to attribute one's successes to internal dispositional factors (e.g., skill, effort) and one's failures to external situational factors (e.g., impossible quotas, absent colleagues). The manager's pattern across both the bonus and missed target episodes fits this definition precisely.
option_explanations.B: The actor-observer bias involves attributing one's own behavior to situational factors and others' behavior to dispositional factors regardless of outcome valence — it does not specifically predict asymmetric attribution based on whether an outcome is a success or failure, so it does not fully account for this pattern.
option_explanations.C: Illusory correlation is the perception of a relationship between variables when no such relationship actually exists. It pertains to how people perceive co-occurrence patterns, not how individuals explain the causes of their own outcomes, making it an incorrect fit here.
option_explanations.D: Defensive attribution refers specifically to the tendency to blame victims for accidents or misfortune in order to preserve a belief in a just world — it is not a self-referential pattern of attributing one's own successes and failures differently, which is what the vignette describes.

questions.source_summary: The self-serving bias is the tendency to attribute our successes to dispositional factors and our failures to situational factors.
questions.subdomain: Social Cognition - Errors, Biases, and Heuristics
questions.vignette: A competitive amateur tennis player wins a local tournament and tells his coach that the victory reflects his years of disciplined training and natural athletic ability. After losing a match the following weekend, he argues that the court surface was different from what he trained on, his opponent used a racket with unusually tight string tension, and the wind conditions were unpredictable. His coach, who has worked with many athletes, recognizes that this causal explanation pattern is common among competitors and typically functions to preserve the athlete's self-image. Notably, the athlete applies this same reasoning regardless of whether external observers consider the situational factors genuinely influential.
questions.question: Which psychological phenomenon BEST explains the athlete's pattern of explaining his wins and losses?

option_explanations.A: The actor-observer bias predicts that people explain their own behavior situationally and others' behavior dispositionally, regardless of outcome valence. Although this might seem plausible because the athlete emphasizes situational factors after losing, the bias does not predict the contrasting dispositional attribution made after winning — that asymmetry is the key distinguishing feature.
option_explanations.B: The self-serving bias precisely captures the athlete's pattern: crediting wins to internal, dispositional factors (training, natural ability) while attributing losses to external, situational factors (court surface, string tension, wind). This bias functions to protect self-esteem and is the most accurate label for the observed pattern.
option_explanations.C: Counterfactual thinking refers to mentally simulating alternative outcomes ('If only I had served differently, I would have won'). While athletes do engage in counterfactual thinking, the vignette describes a causal attribution pattern for actual outcomes, not imaginative simulation of alternatives.
option_explanations.D: Defensive pessimism is a strategy in which individuals set low expectations before a challenging event to reduce anxiety and motivate preparation. It involves anticipatory cognition before an outcome, not retrospective attribution after one — making it an incorrect fit for this vignette.

questions.source_summary: The self-serving bias is the tendency to attribute our successes to dispositional factors and our failures to situational factors.
questions.subdomain: Social Cognition - Errors, Biases, and Heuristics
questions.vignette: A researcher reviewing interview transcripts from a study on workplace performance notices a striking pattern in how mid-level managers explain their outcomes. When projects succeed, managers consistently describe their own judgment, leadership style, and expertise as the driving forces. When projects fail, those same managers emphasize budget cuts imposed from above, inadequate staffing, and market volatility as the critical factors. Importantly, the researcher notes that the managers being observed are talking exclusively about their own projects and outcomes — not about the performance of their subordinates. The researcher considers several explanations and determines that this pattern appears to protect the managers' ego from the implications of failure.
questions.question: Which social psychological concept BEST accounts for the pattern the researcher has identified?

option_explanations.A: The fundamental attribution error involves overattributing others' behavior to dispositional causes while underattributing situational causes — it describes how observers explain other people's actions, not how individuals explain their own successes and failures. Because the managers are exclusively explaining their own outcomes, fundamental attribution error is not the correct label.
option_explanations.B: The actor-observer bias predicts that individuals explain their own behavior situationally and others' behavior dispositionally — a plausible fit here since managers do invoke situational factors. However, the actor-observer bias does not predict the contrasting pattern of dispositional attribution after success; that success-failure asymmetry is the critical feature that distinguishes self-serving bias.
option_explanations.C: The self-serving bias describes the asymmetric attribution pattern in which personal successes are credited to internal, dispositional factors (judgment, expertise) while failures are attributed to external, situational factors (budget cuts, market conditions). The ego-protective function noted by the researcher and the success-failure asymmetry both confirm this as the correct concept.
option_explanations.D: In-group bias refers to the tendency to favor members of one's own group over out-group members in evaluations, resource allocation, and attributions. While managers might apply in-group bias when evaluating subordinates versus external teams, the described pattern involves self-referential attribution across success and failure outcomes — which is not captured by in-group bias.

questions.source_summary: The self-serving bias is the tendency to attribute our successes to dispositional factors and our failures to situational factors.
questions.subdomain: Social Cognition - Errors, Biases, and Heuristics
questions.vignette: A clinical researcher studying health behavior notices that patients recovering from cardiac surgery consistently describe their recovery progress in a particular way. When they heal faster than expected, they cite their own strong willpower, history of physical fitness, and commitment to following medical advice. When setbacks occur — such as infections or slower physical therapy progress — those same patients point to factors like inadequate hospital staffing, poor nutrition in the meals provided, and the unusual severity of their original condition. The researcher, trained in behavioral science, suspects this pattern across multiple patients is not random and notes that peers who learn of a patient's success tend to admire the patient, while peers who hear only of the failure tend to excuse the patient. However, the researcher carefully determines that the pattern originates within the patients' own explanations of their personal outcomes, not in how outside observers judge them.
questions.question: Which phenomenon BEST explains the consistent pattern the researcher has identified in how these patients explain their own recovery outcomes?

option_explanations.A: The fundamental attribution error describes observers' tendency to overweight dispositional causes when explaining other people's behavior. Although the vignette includes a detail about how peers respond to patients' outcomes — a red herring designed to suggest this option — the researcher explicitly determines the pattern originates in how patients explain their own outcomes, not in how others judge them. This rules out fundamental attribution error.
option_explanations.B: The actor-observer bias predicts that individuals explain their own behavior situationally while explaining others' behavior dispositionally. This is a strong distractor because the patients do explain their setbacks situationally. However, the actor-observer bias does not predict that the same individuals will explain their successes dispositionally — that asymmetry based on outcome valence (success vs. failure) is the defining feature of a different phenomenon.
option_explanations.C: Unrealistic optimism is the belief that one is personally less likely than peers to experience negative future events and more likely to experience positive ones. This might seem plausible given the health recovery context, but it is a forward-looking belief about probability, not a retrospective pattern of explaining causes of outcomes that have already occurred — making it an incorrect fit.
option_explanations.D: The self-serving bias is distinguished by its outcome-contingent attribution asymmetry: successes are attributed to internal, dispositional factors (willpower, fitness, adherence) while failures are attributed to external, situational factors (staffing, meal quality, severity of illness). This pattern, applied by the patients to their own outcomes across both positive and negative results, is the defining characteristic of the self-serving bias and precisely matches what the researcher observes.

questions.source_summary: The foot-in-the-door technique is most useful for explaining why "teachers" in Milgram's obedience to authority study complied with the experimenter's order to increase the level of shock they delivered to the "learner".
questions.vignette: In a classic social psychology study, participants acting as 'teachers' were instructed to administer electric shocks to a 'learner' whenever a wrong answer was given. The experimenter used an incremental approach, beginning with a modest 15-volt shock and gradually increasing the voltage in small steps. Researchers noted that the foot-in-the-door dynamic was central to understanding why participants continued to comply with each successive request even as discomfort grew. By the time the shocks reached dangerous levels, most participants had already committed to a pattern of obedience that was difficult to break.
questions.question: Which social influence principle best explains why participants in this study continued to administer increasingly severe shocks despite their reservations?

option_explanations.A: The door-in-the-face technique involves making a large initial request that is refused, then following with a smaller target request. In this study, there was no large initial request that was rejected; instead, requests began small and escalated, making this technique inapplicable.
option_explanations.B: The foot-in-the-door technique explains how agreeing to small initial requests creates a pattern of commitment that makes it increasingly difficult to refuse larger subsequent requests. In Milgram's study, participants began with small, seemingly harmless shocks and incrementally escalated, each step of compliance binding them further to continuing.
option_explanations.C: The reciprocity norm involves feeling obligated to return a favor or concession given by another party. While relevant to some compliance contexts, it does not explain the incremental escalation of shock administration in Milgram's design, which involved no exchange of favors.
option_explanations.D: Normative social influence refers to conforming to group expectations to gain approval or avoid rejection. Milgram's study was an individual obedience paradigm involving no peer group pressure from fellow participants, so normative social influence does not capture the mechanism of incremental compliance here.

questions.source_summary: The foot-in-the-door technique is most useful for explaining why "teachers" in Milgram's obedience to authority study complied with the experimenter's order to increase the level of shock they delivered to the "learner".
questions.vignette: A 45-year-old male participant volunteers for what he believes is a learning and memory study. An experimenter in a lab coat instructs him to deliver a mild electric shock each time another participant — actually a confederate — answers incorrectly. Each subsequent wrong answer is accompanied by an incremental increase of 15 volts. The participant reports feeling anxious and expresses concern about the confederate's well-being, yet continues to follow each successive command. Researchers later note that the participant's obedience appears to be driven not only by the authority of the experimenter, but by the progressive nature of each request building on the one before it.
questions.question: Beyond the authority of the experimenter, which social influence mechanism best explains why the participant continued to comply with each escalating request?

option_explanations.A: Social proof refers to using others' behavior as a cue for how to act in ambiguous situations. Although this participant may look to the experimenter as a reference, social proof is a conformity-based process relying on perceived group behavior, not on the binding effect of sequential small commitments that escalate in size.
option_explanations.B: Cognitive dissonance reduction could explain some of the participant's rationalization of his actions, as he might reduce tension by convincing himself the shocks are necessary. However, this is an internal attitude-change mechanism rather than an external compliance technique; it describes a consequence of compliance, not the structural reason why each step made refusal harder.
option_explanations.C: The foot-in-the-door technique explains how initial agreement to a small request increases the likelihood of complying with progressively larger ones. The incremental 15-volt structure of Milgram's paradigm is a textbook instantiation of this process: each 'yes' creates a commitment that anchors the participant to continuing, even as the requests become more extreme.
option_explanations.D: The door-in-the-face technique requires that a large, unreasonable request be made and refused before a smaller target request is presented. Milgram's paradigm begins with small requests and escalates; there is no large initial request that the participant rejects, so this technique does not apply.

questions.source_summary: The foot-in-the-door technique is most useful for explaining why "teachers" in Milgram's obedience to authority study complied with the experimenter's order to increase the level of shock they delivered to the "learner".
questions.vignette: A social psychology researcher is reviewing archival footage of a classic behavioral study in which participants were assigned a task involving repeated interactions with a distressed confederate. With each interaction, the participants were asked to take slightly more drastic action than before, and many continued even as the confederate's protests grew louder. Participants frequently stated afterward that they had felt trapped — that having already done so much, stopping would mean acknowledging that their earlier actions were wrong. The researcher notes that the apparent authority figure in the room issued commands dressed in the language of scientific necessity, which some colleagues argue is the primary explanation for continued compliance. However, the researcher argues that even controlling for authority, the progressive structure of the requests was the more parsimonious explanation for why refusal felt psychologically costly at each step.
questions.question: The researcher's explanation for continued compliance centers on which social influence mechanism?

option_explanations.A: Obedience to authority is the most commonly cited explanation for Milgram's findings and is indeed a relevant factor here. However, the researcher explicitly argues that even controlling for authority, the progressive escalation structure itself best explains why participants felt psychologically unable to stop — pointing specifically to commitment built through incremental compliance rather than authority per se.
option_explanations.B: Normative social influence involves conforming to group norms to gain acceptance. This study involved a dyadic authority relationship, not peer pressure or group approval-seeking. While social norms around obeying authority may be implicated, normative social influence as a mechanism does not capture the progressive commitment dynamic the researcher identifies.
option_explanations.C: The foot-in-the-door technique explains why a series of escalating requests, each grounded in prior commitment, makes it increasingly difficult to refuse. The researcher's point — that participants felt trapped by their prior actions and that stopping would require acknowledging earlier wrongs — is a direct description of the commitment mechanism underlying this technique.
option_explanations.D: Self-perception theory proposes that people infer their own attitudes by observing their own behavior. While it shares some logical similarity — participants might infer 'I must believe this is okay because I kept doing it' — it is an attitude formation theory, not a compliance technique. It does not explain the structural role of incremental requests in binding participants to continued action.

questions.source_summary: The foot-in-the-door technique is most useful for explaining why "teachers" in Milgram's obedience to authority study complied with the experimenter's order to increase the level of shock they delivered to the "learner".
questions.vignette: During a debrief session following a controversial behavioral experiment, participants describe a curious experience: they recall feeling that each individual step seemed reasonable given the one before it, and that any particular moment of resistance would have required them to repudiate not just the current request but everything they had already agreed to. Several participants described experiencing considerable internal distress yet feeling as though stopping was more costly than continuing. The study's lead investigator, when presenting results, framed her participants' behavior as primarily a product of the perceived legitimacy of the scientific setting and the credentials of the researchers. A consulting social psychologist, however, challenges this interpretation, arguing that the structural design of the escalation sequence itself — independent of who was issuing instructions — was the operative mechanism.
questions.question: The consulting social psychologist's argument most directly invokes which social influence principle?

option_explanations.A: Legitimacy of authority refers to compliance driven by the perceived right of an authority figure to issue commands. The lead investigator favors this explanation, and it fits much of the scenario — but the consulting social psychologist explicitly argues that the escalation structure, independent of who was giving commands, was the key mechanism, which points away from authority-based explanations.
option_explanations.B: Cognitive dissonance involves the discomfort arising from inconsistent cognitions, and participants' internal distress is consistent with this. However, cognitive dissonance is a consequence of behavior — it describes the tension participants experienced — rather than the structural compliance technique that caused the incremental agreement. The social psychologist's argument is about the design of requests, not participants' internal states.
option_explanations.C: The foot-in-the-door technique explains how a sequence of incrementally escalating requests — each building on prior agreement — produces commitment that makes later refusal psychologically costly. Participants' descriptions of feeling unable to stop without repudiating all prior actions, and the psychologist's focus on the structural escalation independent of authority, are precisely what this technique predicts.
option_explanations.D: The low-ball technique involves gaining initial agreement to a request and then revealing additional costs after commitment is secured, making it difficult to withdraw. While it also relies on commitment, the low-ball technique requires concealment of true costs until after initial agreement — here, the increasing severity of each request was transparent throughout, which is the hallmark of foot-in-the-door rather than low-ball.

questions.source_summary: The foot-in-the-door technique is most useful for explaining why "teachers" in Milgram's obedience to authority study complied with the experimenter's order to increase the level of shock they delivered to the "learner".
questions.vignette: A behavioral scientist reviews a study in which volunteers were recruited under the pretense of helping to test educational materials. Each volunteer was repeatedly asked to take a small additional step beyond what they had just done — steps so minor in isolation that declining any single one seemed disproportionately disruptive. Participants later reported that they had felt unable to identify a natural stopping point and described feeling bound by what they had already done. Many expressed that their reluctance to act was not about being told what to do, but about the internal inconsistency that stopping would create given their previous actions. A colleague reviewing the same data suggests that participants were simply responding to the uniform demands of an authoritative figure in the room, and that personal susceptibility to social pressure explains the distribution of outcomes.
questions.question: Which explanation most precisely accounts for the mechanism the participants themselves described as driving their continued participation?

option_explanations.A: Obedience to authority is the explanation the colleague in the vignette endorses and is a highly plausible alternative — the presence of an authoritative figure in the room is mentioned. However, participants themselves specifically described feeling bound not by the authority of who was asking, but by the difficulty of stopping given everything they had already done. This self-report points to a commitment-based mechanism rather than an authority-based one.
option_explanations.B: The foot-in-the-door technique is the mechanism participants' own descriptions most precisely identify: they felt bound by prior compliance, had no clear stopping point because each step was small relative to the last, and experienced stopping as internally inconsistent with their prior behavior. The sequential, incremental structure — where each small agreement made the next harder to refuse — is the defining feature of this technique.
option_explanations.C: The low-ball technique shares some surface features — it also relies on commitment — but it specifically involves concealing true costs of a request until after initial agreement is secured, then revealing those costs once the person is already committed. In this scenario, there is no hidden cost that was revealed after initial agreement; participants were progressively asked for more from the start, which is foot-in-the-door rather than low-ball.
option_explanations.D: Cognitive dissonance is highly tempting here because participants describe an internal tension between their actions and their values, and even explicitly mention the inconsistency that stopping would create. However, cognitive dissonance is a theory about how people resolve psychological discomfort between conflicting cognitions — it describes what participants experienced internally, not the structural technique applied to them that caused continued compliance.

questions.source_summary: According to Tuckman and Jensen's (1977) five-stage model, the development of commitment to a group and willingness to talk about issues and concerns is characteristic of the norming stage.
questions.vignette: A newly formed project team at a consulting firm has been meeting weekly for two months. After a turbulent period of disagreements about roles and responsibilities, the team has recently begun to show increased commitment to the group's shared goals. Members now openly discuss their concerns and personal reservations about the project, something they refused to do in earlier meetings. A social psychologist observing the team notes that this pattern of group development is highly consistent with a recognized theoretical model of team evolution.
questions.question: According to Tuckman and Jensen's (1977) five-stage model of group development, which stage BEST describes the phase this team has entered?

options.A: Storming stage, characterized by conflict over roles and resistance to group influence
options.B: Norming stage, characterized by the development of group commitment and willingness to openly discuss issues
options.C: Performing stage, characterized by flexible role structures and energy directed toward task completion
options.D: Forming stage, characterized by orientation, testing boundaries, and dependence on the leader

option_explanations.A: The storming stage is marked by intragroup conflict, power struggles, and resistance — which the vignette explicitly places in the team's past. The current behavior represents movement beyond storming, not a description of it.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. In Tuckman and Jensen's model, the norming stage is specifically defined by the emergence of group cohesion, commitment to the group, and members' willingness to openly share concerns and work through issues collaboratively.
option_explanations.C: The performing stage follows norming and is characterized by a fully functional, interdependent structure focused on task completion. While the team is progressing, the emphasis here is on newly developing openness and commitment — hallmarks of norming, not yet performing.
option_explanations.D: The forming stage occurs at the group's inception and involves orientation and initial boundary testing. The vignette clearly states the team has been meeting for two months and has already passed through a period of conflict, ruling out the forming stage.

questions.source_summary: According to Tuckman and Jensen's (1977) five-stage model, the development of commitment to a group and willingness to talk about issues and concerns is characteristic of the norming stage.
questions.vignette: A researcher studying team dynamics in a hospital setting observes a surgical support team that was assembled six months ago. Early in its existence, the team experienced significant interpersonal friction and role ambiguity that slowed their work. Now, several of the team members — including one nurse who initially considered leaving — report feeling a strong sense of group cohesion and are notably willing to raise sensitive operational concerns during meetings, concerns they previously kept to themselves. The researcher, who is a 35-year-old organizational psychologist, records that the team has entered a predictable and well-documented phase of development.
questions.question: Based on Tuckman and Jensen's (1977) model of group development, which stage does the team's current behavior BEST exemplify?

options.A: Performing stage, in which members operate flexibly and focus on achieving the group's goals with minimal friction
options.B: Adjourning stage, in which members process the impending dissolution of the group and reflect on shared experiences
options.C: Norming stage, in which cohesion develops and members become willing to openly address issues and concerns
options.D: Storming stage, in which subgroups form and members challenge the leader's authority and group norms

option_explanations.A: The performing stage is marked by efficient, goal-directed collaboration within a stable role structure. While the team is improving, the key descriptors here — newly emerging cohesion and newly expressed willingness to raise concerns — are defining features of norming, which precedes performing.
option_explanations.B: The adjourning stage (the fifth stage added by Jensen) involves the disbandment of the group and associated emotional processing. Nothing in the vignette suggests the team is ending; they are actively engaged and growing, making adjourning clearly incorrect.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. The norming stage in Tuckman and Jensen's model is specifically defined by the emergence of group cohesion and members' newly developed willingness to openly discuss issues and concerns — precisely what is described in this scenario.
option_explanations.D: The storming stage is defined by conflict, resistance, and interpersonal friction — dynamics the vignette explicitly places in the team's past. The team has moved beyond storming into the cohesion and openness characteristic of norming.

questions.source_summary: According to Tuckman and Jensen's (1977) five-stage model, the development of commitment to a group and willingness to talk about issues and concerns is characteristic of the norming stage.
questions.vignette: A facilitator leading a community support group for adults recovering from job loss notes that the group, now in its third month, has undergone a remarkable shift. In early sessions, members were polite but guarded, with most conversation directed toward the facilitator rather than each other. Over the past three weeks, however, members have begun sharing personal fears and setbacks with one another unprompted, and several have expressed feeling genuinely invested in each other's progress. Interestingly, the group has not yet reached the point where members are working in a coordinated, efficient way to solve problems together — they are still adjusting to this new level of openness. The facilitator, drawing on a developmental framework, identifies this as a critical transitional phase in the group's life.
questions.question: According to Tuckman and Jensen's (1977) five-stage model, which stage BEST characterizes this group's current phase of development?

options.A: Performing stage, in which group energy is channeled into productive, goal-directed activity with a stable role structure
options.B: Forming stage, in which members are oriented to one another and test the boundaries of acceptable group behavior
options.C: Adjourning stage, in which the group prepares for termination and members process the meaning of their shared work
options.D: Norming stage, in which members develop commitment to the group and become willing to openly address personal issues and concerns

option_explanations.A: The performing stage is characterized by coordinated, flexible effort directed at the group's goals. The vignette explicitly states the group has not yet reached efficient, coordinated problem-solving — this detail rules out performing and points toward the stage just before it, norming.
option_explanations.B: The forming stage is marked by initial orientation, guardedness, and reliance on the facilitator — behaviors the vignette locates in the group's early sessions, not the present. The current shift toward personal disclosure and mutual investment places the group beyond forming.
option_explanations.C: The adjourning stage concerns the group's dissolution and members' emotional processing of ending. The group is in its third month of ongoing work with no indication it is ending, making adjourning irrelevant to this scenario.
option_explanations.D: This is correct. The norming stage is defined by the emergence of group cohesion and the development of commitment — members become willing to share personal concerns and invest in one another. The vignette's emphasis on newly emerged openness, personal disclosure, and felt investment, combined with the explicit statement that efficient task performance has not yet begun, precisely maps onto norming.

questions.source_summary: According to Tuckman and Jensen's (1977) five-stage model, the development of commitment to a group and willingness to talk about issues and concerns is characteristic of the norming stage.
questions.vignette: A consultant observing a newly formed interdepartmental task force at a technology company notes that after an initial honeymoon period followed by weeks of visible tension over decision-making authority, something has changed. Team members are now actively seeking one another's input and have started voluntarily disclosing concerns about workload and project direction that they previously concealed. The consultant observes that there is still little evidence of the fluid, high-functioning coordination one would expect in a mature team — role assignments remain somewhat tentative and members are still calibrating how direct to be with one another. One senior member remarks that the group finally feels like 'a real team,' suggesting an important interpersonal shift has occurred.
questions.question: Using Tuckman and Jensen's (1977) developmental framework, at which stage is this task force MOST likely operating?

options.A: Storming stage, because the residual tension over decision-making authority remains a salient feature of the group's experience
options.B: Performing stage, because members are now coordinating their efforts and seeking each other's input on task-relevant issues
options.C: Norming stage, because members have developed sufficient commitment and cohesion to begin openly sharing concerns and investing in the group
options.D: Forming stage, because role assignments remain tentative and members are still calibrating their interpersonal behavior with one another

option_explanations.A: The storming stage is characterized by active conflict and resistance to group influence. While the vignette references prior tension, that period is described as past; the current behavior — voluntary disclosure, sought input, felt cohesion — represents movement into the next stage. Residual memory of conflict does not define the current stage.
option_explanations.B: The performing stage involves fluid, efficient role structures and sustained goal-directed collaboration. The vignette explicitly notes the absence of this high-functioning coordination and describes roles as still tentative — details that distinguish norming from performing and rule out this option.
option_explanations.C: This is correct. The norming stage is specifically defined by the emergence of group commitment and members' willingness to openly discuss concerns. The senior member's remark that the group 'finally feels like a real team,' combined with voluntary disclosure and sought input despite still-tentative roles, precisely characterizes the norming stage.
option_explanations.D: Tentative role assignments and calibrating interpersonal behavior could superficially suggest forming, but forming precedes conflict and is marked by initial orientation and reliance on leadership. The group has clearly passed through a storming period, and the interpersonal shift toward openness and cohesion is inconsistent with the cautious, leader-dependent dynamics of forming.

questions.vignette: A graduate student studying a volunteer crisis hotline team observes the following: for the first several weeks, team members were friendly but kept conversations focused on logistics. This was followed by a difficult stretch during which two senior members clashed repeatedly over how calls should be handled, creating visible tension among the rest of the team. Now, in recent weeks, something has shifted — members have started bringing up their own doubts and anxieties about handling difficult calls, and several have acknowledged feeling a personal stake in whether the team succeeds. The team has not yet reached the point where everyone moves seamlessly from task to task; there are still occasional awkward pauses and moments of uncertainty about who should take the lead. One member mentioned that the team 'finally feels safe enough to be honest,' which the graduate student finds theoretically significant.
questions.question: Which stage of small group development does the team's CURRENT behavior MOST accurately reflect?

options.A: The second stage of group development, in which power struggles and resistance to established procedures dominate the group's process
options.B: The third stage of group development, in which members develop mutual trust and a felt sense of belonging that enables open sharing of concerns
options.C: The fourth stage of group development, in which members function interdependently and direct their energy toward accomplishing shared goals
options.D: The first stage of group development, in which members are orienting to one another and the primary focus is on establishing the parameters of participation

option_explanations.A: The second stage (storming) is defined by active conflict, power struggles, and resistance — dynamics the vignette clearly places in the team's recent past. The current behavior has moved beyond interpersonal conflict into something qualitatively different: voluntary disclosure and a felt sense of investment, which belong to the third stage.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The third stage (norming) in Tuckman and Jensen's model is characterized by the development of group cohesion, commitment, and — critically — members' willingness to openly raise their own doubts and concerns. The member's comment about the team 'finally feeling safe enough to be honest,' combined with personal disclosure and felt investment, precisely defines norming. The persistence of minor awkwardness and role uncertainty confirms the group has not yet reached the performing stage.
option_explanations.C: The fourth stage (performing) is marked by seamless, interdependent functioning and sustained task-directed energy. The vignette explicitly describes the absence of this smooth coordination — awkward pauses and role uncertainty remain — ruling out performing. Selecting this option requires ignoring the vignette's direct statement that the team has not yet reached fluid, coordinated action.
option_explanations.D: The first stage (forming) involves initial orientation, polite surface behavior, and boundary testing — dynamics the vignette places at the team's earliest weeks, not the present. The group has clearly passed through both forming and storming; attributing the current state to forming ignores the developmental arc the vignette carefully traces.

questions.source_summary: Esther will be motivated to change her attitude toward her roommate or golf if she learns that her roommate loathes golf, according to Heider's balance theory.
questions.vignette: A social psychology textbook presents a classic triadic relationship scenario: Esther likes her roommate Priya very much. Esther also holds a positive attitude toward golf. When Esther discovers that Priya loathes golf, the triad becomes imbalanced. According to balance theory, this imbalanced state creates psychological tension, motivating attitude change to restore equilibrium.
questions.question: Which theoretical framework best explains why Esther is motivated to change her attitude toward either Priya or golf?

options.A: Cognitive dissonance theory, because Esther's two inconsistent cognitions create internal arousal that must be resolved by changing a belief.
options.B: Heider's balance theory, because the triadic relationship among Esther, Priya, and golf is imbalanced, creating pressure to restore a balanced state.
options.C: Social comparison theory, because Esther evaluates her attitude toward golf by comparing it to Priya's attitude.
options.D: Elaboration likelihood model, because Esther is processing information about Priya's golf attitude through a central route.

option_explanations.A: Cognitive dissonance theory (Festinger) focuses on inconsistency between a person's own beliefs or behaviors, producing aversive arousal. While it shares a consistency-seeking motive, it does not specifically model triadic person-person-object relationships or the structural balance logic that applies here.
option_explanations.B: Correct. Heider's balance theory specifically predicts that a P-O-X triad (Esther-Priya-golf) becomes imbalanced when two of the three relationships are positive and one is negative (or vice versa). This imbalance motivates one of the three parties to shift an attitude to restore balance.
option_explanations.C: Social comparison theory (Festinger) holds that people evaluate their own opinions and abilities by comparing them to others, typically in domains with no objective standard. It does not model triadic structural balance or predict attitude change pressure in the way described here.
option_explanations.D: The elaboration likelihood model (Petty & Cacioppo) describes two routes of persuasion — central (argument quality) and peripheral (cues). It concerns how persuasive messages are processed, not the structural consistency of interpersonal relationship triads.

questions.source_summary: Esther will be motivated to change her attitude toward her roommate or golf if she learns that her roommate loathes golf, according to Heider's balance theory.
questions.vignette: Esther, a 28-year-old recreational athlete, has been close friends with her new roommate for three months and genuinely admires her. Esther recently took up golf and developed a strong enthusiasm for the sport. During a casual conversation, her roommate reveals an intense dislike of golf, finding it elitist and tedious. Esther later reports feeling an inexplicable sense of tension or unease about the situation, even though nothing hostile was said. A researcher notes that this discomfort arises from a disruption in interpersonal consistency within their social triad.
questions.question: What best explains the psychological tension Esther experiences after learning her roommate dislikes golf?

options.A: Heider's balance theory, because the person-person-object triad is imbalanced — Esther likes her roommate, Esther likes golf, but her roommate dislikes golf — producing pressure to restore a balanced triad.
options.B: Cognitive dissonance theory, because Esther's own attitude toward golf conflicts with a behavior she has recently performed, generating aversive arousal.
options.C: Newcomb's A-B-X symmetry model, because communication breakdowns between Esther and her roommate about golf have disrupted their co-orientation toward a shared attitude object.
options.D: Consistency motive under social identity theory, because Esther's in-group membership with her roommate threatens her self-concept when group norms conflict with personal attitudes.

option_explanations.A: Correct. Heider's balance theory predicts that when a person (P) likes another person (O) and P likes an object (X), but O dislikes X, the triad is unbalanced (+, +, −). This structural imbalance produces tension motivating P to change either the P-O or the P-X relationship to restore balance.
option_explanations.B: Cognitive dissonance theory applies when a person's own cognitions or behaviors are inconsistent with each other. The vignette does not describe Esther acting contrary to her own attitude; instead, the tension arises from a third party's (her roommate's) discrepant attitude — a triadic, not dyadic, inconsistency.
option_explanations.C: Newcomb's A-B-X symmetry model is closely related to balance theory and does address co-orientation between two people toward an attitude object. However, the vignette emphasizes Heider's original structural balance formulation rather than Newcomb's communication-focused extension, and the tension arises from structural imbalance, not a communication breakdown per se.
option_explanations.D: Social identity theory (Tajfel & Turner) concerns how group membership shapes self-concept and intergroup behavior. While it involves in-group norms, it does not specifically model triadic person-person-object balance dynamics or predict the precise pattern of tension described here.

questions.source_summary: Esther will be motivated to change her attitude toward her roommate or golf if she learns that her roommate loathes golf, according to Heider's balance theory.
questions.vignette: Esther has been roommates with Mei for four months and holds her in high regard. Over time, Esther has cultivated a deep passion for golf, spending weekends at the driving range. Last week, Mei casually but emphatically mentioned that she finds golf pointless and a waste of time. Esther noticed she began thinking more critically about golf's value afterward — even though Mei never pressured her and Esther did not want to disappoint her friend. Notably, Esther had not played golf recently and had not made any public commitment to the sport.
questions.question: Which principle most precisely explains why Esther began to privately reconsider her enthusiasm for golf?

options.A: Normative social influence, because Esther changed her private attitude about golf to align with Mei's expressed opinion to avoid social disapproval and maintain the friendship.
options.B: Heider's balance theory, because the triad formed by Esther, Mei, and golf is structurally imbalanced, creating internal pressure for Esther to alter an attitude to restore consistency.
options.C: Cognitive dissonance theory, because Esther's positive attitude toward golf is inconsistent with her positive relationship with Mei, generating aversive self-relevant arousal that motivates attitude change.
options.D: Informational social influence, because Esther treats Mei's negative opinion of golf as useful evidence about golf's true value, updating her attitude based on this new information.

option_explanations.B: Correct. Heider's balance theory focuses precisely on the structural consistency of triadic relationships. Esther (P) likes Mei (O) and likes golf (X), but Mei dislikes golf (−). This yields a P+O, P+X, O−X triad — an imbalanced configuration — which motivates Esther to adjust either her attitude toward golf or toward Mei to restore balance, even without external pressure.
option_explanations.A: Normative social influence involves changing one's expressed behavior or attitude to gain approval or avoid disapproval from others. It would be more apt if Esther changed her public behavior to fit in; however, the vignette specifies private attitude reconsideration without social pressure, which is not the primary mechanism normative influence addresses.
option_explanations.C: Cognitive dissonance theory is a compelling distractor here because it also involves inconsistency between cognitions. However, dissonance classically requires that the inconsistency be between the person's own cognitions or between a cognition and a behavior. The tension here is structurally triadic (involving a third party's attitude), which is more precisely captured by balance theory.
option_explanations.D: Informational social influence occurs when a person accepts another's opinion as credible evidence about reality, especially in ambiguous situations. Although Esther might use Mei's view as information, the vignette emphasizes the structural relationship dynamic rather than an evidence-updating process, and golf's value is not described as ambiguous or uncertain to Esther.

questions.source_summary: Esther will be motivated to change her attitude toward her roommate or golf if she learns that her roommate loathes golf, according to Heider's balance theory.
questions.vignette: Esther has spent years cultivating a love of golf and considers it central to her personal identity. She recently moved in with a new roommate, Lena, and quickly developed a warm, mutually appreciative friendship with her. During a weekend outing, Lena offhandedly but sincerely expressed that she considers golf a frivolous, exclusionary hobby. Esther did not say anything in response and later told a friend that she felt oddly unsettled — not because Lena criticized her, but because she found herself unexpectedly questioning whether golf was really worth her time. Esther's therapist noted that her discomfort seemed linked to a desire to restore psychological equilibrium within an important relationship.
questions.question: The therapist's observation most directly implicates which underlying psychological mechanism?

options.A: Cognitive dissonance reduction, in which Esther's strong self-identification with golf conflicts with a new, threat-relevant cognition about golf introduced by Lena's comment, motivating her to revise her self-concept.
options.B: Heider's balance theory, in which structural imbalance among Esther, Lena, and golf — two positive and one negative relational link — creates pressure to alter one link and restore a balanced triadic configuration.
options.C: Reactance theory, in which Esther's threatened freedom to enjoy golf motivates her to bolster her positive attitude toward golf rather than question it, but the internal tension is mislabeled as 'unsettlement' by her therapist.
options.D: Assimilation effect under social judgment theory, in which Lena's highly discrepant negative attitude toward golf falls within Esther's latitude of rejection, leading Esther to contrast her own attitude away from Lena's rather than reconsider it.

option_explanations.A: Cognitive dissonance is a highly plausible distractor here because Esther's self-identity is linked to golf and Lena's comment introduces an inconsistency. However, classical dissonance theory requires an inconsistency between the individual's own cognitions or between a cognition and a behavior. The vignette describes a triadic structural imbalance involving a third party's attitude — precisely the domain of Heider's balance theory — not a self-generated inconsistency.
option_explanations.B: Correct. The therapist's explicit reference to 'restoring psychological equilibrium within an important relationship' directly maps onto Heider's balance theory, which models the P-O-X triad. Esther (P) has positive affect for Lena (O) and golf (X), while Lena holds a negative attitude toward golf (O−X = negative). The resulting imbalanced triad motivates Esther to restore balance by reconsidering her attitude toward golf or Lena — consistent with her reported self-questioning.
option_explanations.C: Reactance theory (Brehm) predicts that when a perceived freedom is threatened, individuals are motivated to reassert that freedom — typically by intensifying the threatened attitude or behavior. This would predict Esther defending golf more strongly, not questioning it, making reactance theory inconsistent with the described outcome of self-doubt and unsettlement.
option_explanations.D: Social judgment theory distinguishes latitudes of acceptance, rejection, and noncommitment. The assimilation effect occurs when a message falls within the latitude of acceptance and the attitude shifts toward it. The contrast effect occurs for messages in the latitude of rejection, pushing attitudes further away. Given Esther's strong pro-golf identity, Lena's view would likely fall in her latitude of rejection and trigger contrast (reinforcing her love of golf), not the questioning behavior described — ruling this option out.

questions.source_summary: Esther will be motivated to change her attitude toward her roommate or golf if she learns that her roommate loathes golf, according to Heider's balance theory.
questions.vignette: Esther has invested considerable time and money into learning golf over the past two years and thinks of it as one of her most cherished hobbies. After moving into a new apartment, she quickly bonded with her roommate, finding her thoughtful, funny, and easy to live with. One evening over dinner, the roommate mentioned — without any intent to criticize Esther — that she finds golf dull, elitist, and not worth anyone's time. Esther did not respond defensively and did not feel personally attacked. Nevertheless, over the following days she found herself spontaneously wondering whether golf was really as enjoyable as she had thought, despite no new experiences with the sport itself. She had made no public statements about golf, had not recently played, and no one had urged her to reconsider.
questions.question: Which psychological principle best accounts for the spontaneous, unprompted shift in Esther's private reconsideration of golf?

options.A: Festinger's theory of cognitive dissonance, in which Esther's strong personal investment in golf creates an inconsistency when a valued other disparages it, motivating her to reduce the resulting aversive tension by reassessing the attitude.
options.B: Heider's balance theory, in which Esther's positive regard for her roommate combined with the roommate's negative evaluation of golf creates a structurally inconsistent configuration, internally motivating Esther to reconsider one of those evaluations.
options.C: Social comparison theory, in which Esther lacks objective criteria for evaluating golf's worth and therefore uses her roommate — a subjectively similar and trusted person — as a social reference point, updating her attitude accordingly.
options.D: Informational social influence, in which Esther treats her roommate's credible, sincere opinion about golf as reliable evidence about golf's true value, leading her to internalize and incorporate that view into her own attitude.

option_explanations.A: Cognitive dissonance is the strongest distractor in this item. Esther's deep personal investment in golf makes her sense of self feel implicated when a liked other devalues it, which resembles self-relevant dissonance. However, classical dissonance requires the inconsistency to reside within the person's own cognition-behavior system. Here, no personal behavior contradicts her attitude, and the tension arises from a third party's evaluation forming an imbalanced relational triad — the defining feature of Heider's balance theory, not dissonance.
option_explanations.B: Correct. Heider's balance theory is the most precise explanation. The three elements — Esther (P), roommate (O), and golf (X) — form a P+O, P+X, O−X triad that is structurally imbalanced. This imbalance generates internal pressure to change one link without any external pressure, public commitment, or behavioral inconsistency required. The absence of defensiveness, public statements, or recent behavior makes dissonance less applicable, while the interpersonal relational structure points directly to balance theory.
option_explanations.C: Social comparison theory (Festinger) predicts that people use others as reference points when objective standards for evaluation are unavailable. This is a plausible distractor because golf's value is somewhat subjective. However, the theory does not predict spontaneous internal pressure arising from the structural configuration of a relationship; it predicts deliberate comparison seeking. The vignette describes spontaneous reconsideration driven by relational structure, not evaluation under uncertainty.
option_explanations.D: Informational social influence involves accepting another's view as credible evidence about reality, typically in ambiguous or uncertain situations. This is a strong distractor because Esther respects her roommate and golf's value is subjective. However, informational influence is a social process tied to uncertainty and credibility cues; it does not explain the specific structural pressure generated by the triadic imbalance or why Esther — who already has two years of direct experience with golf — would be driven by structural tension alone, independent of credibility assessment.

questions.source_summary: Research found that a communicator's credibility is affected primarily by their expertise and trustworthiness.
questions.vignette: A researcher studying persuasion recruits two speakers to deliver identical pro-vaccination messages to separate audiences. The first speaker is introduced as a board-certified immunologist with 20 years of clinical experience and no financial ties to pharmaceutical companies. The second speaker is introduced as a general enthusiast with no formal medical background who recently received funding from a vaccine manufacturer. Post-message attitude surveys reveal that the first speaker produced significantly greater attitude change toward vaccination. The researcher concludes that the difference in audience response is explained by differences in the speakers' perceived credibility, specifically their expertise and trustworthiness.
questions.question: Which concept from research on persuasion BEST explains why the immunologist produced greater attitude change than the enthusiast?

option_explanations.A: Correct. Source credibility refers to a communicator's perceived expertise and trustworthiness, both of which were directly manipulated here. Research consistently shows that higher-credibility sources produce greater attitude change because audiences are more likely to accept arguments from sources they view as knowledgeable and unbiased.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Cognitive dissonance is the discomfort experienced when one holds conflicting beliefs or when behavior contradicts attitudes. It drives attitude change through internal inconsistency, not through perceptions of the speaker's qualifications or motivations.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. The mere exposure effect refers to increased liking for stimuli simply as a result of repeated exposure. It does not involve evaluations of a speaker's expertise or financial conflicts of interest, which are the central factors in this scenario.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. The reciprocity norm is the social obligation to return favors or concessions. It is relevant to compliance and negotiation contexts, not to differences in attitude change based on a speaker's professional background or perceived impartiality.

questions.source_summary: Research found that a communicator's credibility is affected primarily by their expertise and trustworthiness.
